MissionCommands.Message: Welcome back to the Gemini Academy. In this lesson, we will learn how to ignite those engines of this 125 feet tall Titan II rocket, and ride it into orbit.

The time to ignition has been set to 30 minutes. However, if you need more time, you can use the [C] button to toggle the function bubbles, and press "HOLD COUNTDOWN" to stop the countdown. Pressing it again will resume the countdown.
First, we need to repeat the steps we learned in Lesson 1, however, instead of me telling you what to do, we will use the provided checklists.
Press M to toggle the mission pad, and click the CHECKLISTS tab. From here, select the PRE-FLIGHT checklist. On the top right side of the checklist, press the RUN button.
The guide will highlight the steps you need to take to complete checklist. Start to follow the steps highlighted by the Checklist Guide.

When the computer and its display is powered, the computer will perform its self-check routine. This usually takes 20 seconds and can be seen on the computer display on the pilots side. The digits will roll through a sequence, and when complete, stop rolling and reset back to all zeros.

You just started the computer. At this stage, take a look at the commanders attitude ball. It should now slowly roll and align itself to the pre-programmed launch azimuth. If will first roll quite fast, and then fine tune. The total alignment time is 45 seconds, so wait for 45 seconds now.
Verify that the platform is aligned by checking that there is no movement on the attitude ball.

The checklist will ask you to insert the D-RING. The D-RING should already be installed, but can be toggled using the "TOGGLE D-RING" circular function bubble under the commanders panel (toggled by pressing [C]).
Complete the checklist.
Let us go through a typical Gemini ascent.
The Gemini ascent is guided into orbit automatically. The main parts of the ascent guidance program is the roll program and the pitch program.
The roll program will roll the rocket to the pre-programmed ascent azimuth. This happens right after lift-off.

After the roll program is complete, the pitch program will start. This will pitch the rocket towards and even below the horizon, as needed by the ascent guidance program. It will be a slow pitch down from 90 degrees.

Right after engine ignition and when the tower releases the rocket, you will first look for the GREEN light on the computer control panel. This means that the computer has automatically started the ascent program.
Next you need to verify that the clock has started.
Then check the Altimeter to verify that the rocket is climbing.
Then you need to check the fuel and oxidizer indicator for the first stage. It will slowly decreas from full to depleted as fuel and oxidizer in the first stage is consumed.
Then periodically check the G-forces. It is normal that this can reach up to 6G during ascent.
When the altimeter reach 75.000 ft, use the [C] menu to hide the D-RING.
The cabin pressure will slowly decrease during ascent, and stabilize at 5.5.
Staging will occur when the Stage 1 fuel/oxid is depleted, or after a set time has been reached.
The 2nd stage will ignite during stage 1 separation, and will carry the rocket into orbit.
Just as during stage 1, you can monitor the stage 2 fuel/oxid. This will also decrease from full to empty as fuel/oxid is consumed by the stage 2 engines.
During ascent, periodically monitor the electrical power system (preferably every minute). This can be done using the voltmeter selector.
By turning the selector, the voltmeter will show the current voltage of each battery, fuel cell section and DC busses. Check that all components has a volgtage of 23 - 27 vdc.
Now that the computer is running, the platform is aligned, and the final pre-flight checklist is complete, you are ready to launch. If you used the "HOLD COUNTDOWN" feature, resume the countdown now.

Verify that the countdown to launch is counting down, then use Timescale (press alpha numerical keys 1 - 9) to complete the countdown to launch. It will automatically stop the timescale at T -12 seconds.
Bolts! Engines thrusting! One LR87-AJ-7 engine with two nozzles is producing 1913 kN of thrust.
Liftoff for {{capsuleName}}!

During launch, it is important to pay attention to your instruments. You should sit on the left seat (commanders side) and look at the instruments in front of you. You should develop a vision circle, going through vital info in turn.
I will now repeat some of the details outlined during pre-launch.
First check that the computer is started by checking that the COMP light is green, then verify that the mission clock is couting upwards.
During the first 100.000ft, start with the Altimeter. This should be climbing steadily.
Next, keep an eye of the fuel and oxidizer indicator for the current stage. The fuel level indicates time left to the first staging.
Then, ensure the G-forces are within limits. It is normal that this can reach up to 6G during ascent.
The attitude indicator, or ADI (Attitude Direction Indicator) can be used to see direction. You start going up at 90 degrees pitch, then slowly level with horizon.

The Voltmeter (pilot panel, right seat) is there to aid you in knowing your electrical systems are operating normally. The voltmeter selector can be used to select what component to monitor. If you have low voltage somewhere, something is wrong.
The Cabin pressure and CO2 level should be frequently monitored. Cabin PSIG should leak and stabilize at 5.5 during ascent.
The Titan II has two stages with an adapter in-between, currently stage 1 is burning.
When the Altimeter shows 75.000 ft, uninstall the D-RING by toggeling it off using the [C] menu -> TOGGLE D-RING.

You can use the [C] button to see the "Mission Objectives" window (feel free to unbind this from [C] and instead set it to for example [O] if you want to toggle this independently). This shows what the mission is waiting for. You can also always check the radio transcript from the Mission Pad.
Separation! Stage II is equipped with an LR91-AJ-7 engine, producing 445 kN of thrust.
The rocket will now focus on building orbital speed to insert the spaceship into a parking orbit around Earth.
An important feature of the Gemini capsule is that it is equipped with translational thrusters in addition to attitude thrusters. This allows the capsule to modify its orbit in flight.
You can monitor the Stage II propellant state using the FUEL 2/OXID gauge. This will give you an indication of how much time it is left before you are in orbit.
Once you reach orbit, the computers ASCENT module will calculate the distance left to enter the initial parking orbit based on the flight plan.

On the left side (commanders seat), just below the attitude ball, you can see the Incremental Velocity Indicator (IVI) - a device with 3 digits, 6 lights, and 3 selectors. Once Stage II is complete, the computer will show you the velocity difference using the FWD/AFT (leftmost) digit.
We will do this once we have a successful Stage II cutoff. Enjoy the flight for now, and keep monitoring the gauges and instruments just discussed.

Cutoff! While the computer is calculating, let's separate Stage II. You should now see a SEQUENCER LIGHT illuminating yellow on the upper/left side of the center panel (between the commanders left and pilots right panels).

When you see SEP SPCFT is illuminated, open it by left clicking the cover. This will expose a button. Left click the button below it to execute the trigger. This will use the squibs and pyros to separate Stage II.
Great! Another important step is to jettison the Horizon Scanner covers. Do this by opening the JETT FAIRING protection cover (above the SEP SPCFT button), and pressing the JETT FAIRING button.
Good. The Horizon Scanners will now prepare for scanning, and start detecting Earth. This usually takes up to two minutes, and the platform will snap to the new orientation at this point.
Now, let's go back to the IVI again. The IVI is controlled by the computer and is used frequently throughout a mission. It is important to pay attention to this last section of this lesson.

When the launch vehicle inserts you into orbit, there might be a difference between the planned orbit and your actual orbit. The IVIs will indicate the difference, and you can use something called the Orbit Attitude and Maneuvering System (OAMS) to try and null them.

The middle value labelled L/R is the difference in plane, and is only used as informational data on insertion. Plane changes are expensive and slow, and should ideally be done at the "nodes". So what are these "nodes"?

The nodes are basically the point in orbit where the spacecraft crosses the equatorial plane. If the vessel crosses the equator from south to north, the thrust should be to the left to increase the inclination, and to the right to decrease it. The opposite is true if the vessel is moving from north to south.
On insertion this value should be close to zero if your ascent was nominal.

If this value is large, it means that the guidance in the launch vehicle has failed, typically because the inertial reference did not get enough time to align before ascent. It requires 45 seconds to align.
If the inclination shows 999, it usually means that the platform alignment step was forgotten or done incorrectly when performing the pre-launch checklist.

The FWD/AFT labelled value modifies the altitudes of your orbit, meaning Perigee and Apogee. If you are at Pe, typically when inserted, it will be fast to modify this. If you are closer to the nodes, it will be slower to modify this.

If your ascent was nominal, this value (AFT/FWD) should be close to zero. The green lights (+/-) above and below the AFT/FWD digit shows the direction you need to correct the orbit, if the digit is not all zeros.
In most missions, if this value is quite small (less than 10), no corrections are typically needed as later burns will correct it anyways.
If the value shows a FWD burn, a correction is safe and can now be done on insertion.
It is very important to correct a FWD burn if the leftmost IVI digit shows a large value with the plus/fwd light illumintated.
If this is large, it means the launch vehicle was not able to reach the target insertion velocity, and there is a risk that the spacecraft is on a re-entry trajectory.
If the value shows an AFT burn, care should be taken as you might collide with the launch vehicle you just separated from. If a small AFT burn is indicated, ignore the IVI request.
Fow now, let us try to maneuver the spacecraft and see how it affects the IVIs.
To modify your orbit and null the IVIs, you need to use a system called the Orbit Attitude and Maneuvering System (OAMS).
You need to enable the Orbit Attitude and Maneuvering System (OAMS) system to fire the thrusters. This is done with two switches.

First, the propulsion valves needs to be open so the system receives propellant. You already did this in the pre-flight checklist when setting the OAMS PROP MOTOR VALVES to OPEN on the center pedestal.
Next, enable power to the system using CNTL PWR OAMS, set it to ON.
The OAMS system is enabled. It is very important that you always disable the OAMS system directly after use to reduce the possibility to bump into the translational joystick.
Take a note of the current FWD/AFT IVI value, you will return to it soon.
Now you can use the translational stick to execute translational maneuvering on the spacecraft. Use [H] to translate forward and notice how it impafts the leftmost digit on the IVI display.

You can translate AFT using [N], but do not go behind the initial IVI value you took note of before. Take care to not hit the launch vehicle while doing so, but play around with the FWD and AFT translation and notice how it affects the IVIs.
After testing FWD and AFT translational maneuvering, return back to the initial IVI value.
Let us summarize how you read the IVis.
If any of the values shows nominal data (less than 10), the correction burn on insertion can be skipped.

If the IVIs L/R digit (center digit) shows off-nominal values, the launch vehicle was not able to insert you into the correct inclination around Earth and a "Plane Change" burn will need to be planned (covered in a later tutorial).
Off-nominal values here such as large differences can indicate that the platform was not properly aligned during pre-launch.
If the leftmost digt shows a large FWD, you need to zero it to ensure you are in a safe orbit.
If the leftmost digt shows any AFT corrections, you should skip it and correct it with a burn later, to avoid colliding with the launch vehicle.
When you are done with the IVIs and the correction burns, set the computer mode to the "CATCH UP" mode to rotating the mode selector in the computer section.
Since the spacecraft is now in Rate Command mode (this will be covered later), you also have attitude control of the space craft.
Try to use [W][S] to pitch,[A]/[D] to yaw and [Q]/[E] to roll the spacecraft, and see if you are able to center the launch vehicle in the commanders window.

You can also translate the spacecraft up and down using [I]/[K] or left and right using [J]/[L]. Try to do this now. If you have the launch vehicle centered in your window, you can see how it moves relative to you as you translate.
This ends the lesson, feel free to use the ESC-menu to end the session. [Mission completed!]

Title: Tutorial 2 - Ascent of a Titan
Description: The Titan-II is the Launch Vehicle of the Gemini Program. In this lesson we will learn how to ascend into orbit using the Titan.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

Perform the final checks using the checklists, then ascend into Orbit. Patrick, the instructor, will join you in the co-pilot seat.
